Pres. Enforces Pledge

Analysis

Grad.Poll On Policy
By LOUIS GOLDBERG
Goldberg is a graduate student in the department of
Social Relations. He was the founder of the Hopkins Committee on Basiz Freedoms, and is currently on the steering
committee of the Graduate Student Viet Nam Coordinating
Committee.
At the same time that the Student Council was polling
undergraduate opinion on alternative American policies for
the War in Viet Nam last week, the Graduate Committee on
Viet Nani was conducting an identical poll among graduate
students. A considerably smaller number of graduate students voted than was the case for the undergraduates (170
graduate students voted as compared to 805 undergraduates). But while the smaller percentage of graduate students
polled (15% of the graduate students as compared to 54%
of the undregracls voted) raises some cautions in interpretation of the results-----due to questions concerning the representativeness of those who voted—the differences between the
distribution of graduate student votes across the 5 alternatives presented on the ballot, and that of the undergraduates.
Is large enough to indicate the existence of a sharp cleavage
in orientation toward the Viet Nam war between the two
groups.
For while the results of the poll show the Undergraduates as tending to favor "escalation the LBJ way," or an
even more Hawkish stance, the graduate students are clearly
more pacific—with "doves" predominating. Table I shows
these differences.

Whereas only a small minority of undergraduates favor
American withdrawal or a unilateral ceasefire, these two alternatives were preferred by a slight majority of the graduate students who voted.
Since the graduate students were asked to write their
departments on the ballots, and since two-thirds or 113 did
so, it is possible to take a closer look at where the "deescalators" were coming from. Collapsing the five voting alternatives into three categories (De-escalate, LBJ's present
policy, Escalate) and grouping departments into the five categories of (1) Humanities (Art, Philosophy, Romance Languages, Classics, English, Writing Seminar); (2) Social Sciences (Social Relations, Political Science, Political Economy,
History, International Studies); (3) Biological Sciences (Biology, Bio-Medicine, Bio-Physics, School of Hygiene); (4)

An enterprising group of Hopkins students with an interest in art and a flair for
business will open an art gallery in Baltimore early in February. Bruce Schwartz,
originator of the idea, explained "Good students in the fine arts have trouble showing
and selling their work. The National Student Art Exchange is set up strictly for
students, and this will give the best of them
the opportunity to display their work."
Works will be selected by faculties of the
respective schools of the contributors, by
local dealers, and by other qualified students. The first exhibit will feature work
from nearby universities, among them
American University, George Washington
University, University of Maryland, Goucher, and Hopkins.
Schwartz envisions the expansion of the
Art Exchange throughout the East. A gallery opening is planned for Hartford, Conn.,
In April, and one in New York by June.
Also planned is a national art show, to be
held next fall in Baltimore. Sponsored by
Baltimore businesses, it would feature
work contributed by students from the entire eastern United States,

...

Financial Support
Financial backing for the venture originated with a dozen students, mostly undergraduates, who issued stock at $50 a share
and incorporated last December 16 as the
National Student Art Exchange, Inc. The
stock has since split at five for two, with
shares currently selling at $20. The price
will rise to $30 in February. Presently, the
corporation has 78 stockholders, all students.
Schwartz stated that "we are going after
that segment of the market that can't at
ford to buy at $10,000 DeKooning, so in.
stead buys a $200 Chagal lithograph, of
which there are 10,000 copies in the United
States." Works will range from $5 to $200,
and works in every medium will be available.
Located at 833 N. Charles St., the gallery
will . be open Monday through Thursday,
from 1 to 9'p.m., and Friday and Saturday
from 1 p.m. to 1 a.m. Working on commission as brokers, students will be in cornplete charge of the gallery. Stockholders
will be given preference as salesmen, with
each getting a wage of $1 per hour.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, JANUARY 21, 1966

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE THREE

360 German Flight Phi Psi Rush Under Review
Offers Work,Tour
(Continued from Page 1)

Hopkins' personnel Interested
In seeing Germany this summer
can avail themselves of a unique
opportunity. A group flight has
been arranged on which students,
faculty, alumni, employees and
their relatives are eligible. The
flight from New York to Frankfurt departs June 15 and returns
September 6.
Students interested in summer
jobs in Germany can apply at
the Lufthansa office on 330
North Charles Street. Students
must agree to work at least two
months, be 18 years old and have
United States or Canadian citizenship. Applicants should also
have a working knowledge of
German.
Jobs Available
Jobs are available in all areas
of Germany except West Berlin.
The exact location will often be
determined by the type of employment. Openings are available
in agriculture, industry, hotels
and restaurants, construction,

and hospitals.
A time lapse of at least two
months must be expected between application and the actual
offer of a job in Germany, so interested students should apply
promptly. No applications can be
accepted after February 28, 1966
for students planning to Germany independently. January 31,
1966 is the deadline for those who
plan to go on the Hopkins' group
flight.
Wages will generally range
from 60 cents to 80 cents an
hour. Though low by North
American standards, they are
quite adequate in Germany. A
specific statement of wages and
any extra form of renumeration,
such as meals and accommodations, will be included in every
job offer. Those interested in job
applications and/or further information on the group flight
should contact Mike Brenon
(235-4558) or,Mrs. Hazel Maines,
Jenkins 101, extension 429.

WATCH REPAIRING

Editors Note: The following was submitted by a member of the Phi Kappa Psi
Fraternity in clarification of the issue of its probation and its ,plea for reprieve
from the Inter-Fraternity Council.
Time often has a dulling effect upon our
minds. We often lose track of our original
goals and purposes over long periods of time,
and wind up heading in a direction which we
never intended in the first place.
Last Friday's meeting of the Inter-Fraternity
Council and its decision to do nothing about
the social probationary status of the Phi Kappa
Psi Fraternity is a clear example of how our
original intentions can be led astray. Let us
examine the situation which led to the placing
of Phi Psi on probation and then let us
weigh it against the action of the I.F.C.
. Eight pledges from Phi Psi created a community uproar by attempting to take down
the flag at Fort McHenry. Public sentiment
demanded immediate action. The administration acted quickly, placing the individuals involved on social probation and allocating penalties to each. The I.F.C. also acted, for the
Phi Psi brotherhood had accepted full responsibility for the action of their pledges, and
placed Phi Psi under social probation for a
year.
This was the second time that a fraternity
had been placed on social probation by the
I.F.C. However, the restrictions placed upon
Phi Psi were without precedent. Never before
had a fraternity been forbidden to engage in
B.I.A. fraternity competition or to pledge anyone. It was the understanding of all parties
concerned at the hearing last spring that these
measures had to be taken to appease public
commotion over the flag incident. Also the representatives of Phi Psi were led to believe that
their case would be reviewed at the end of the
first semester of this year. If the Fraternity
had lived up to the restrictions placed upon it
and if the incident had become a dead one
publicly, Phi Psis were led to believe that they
would be reinstated to normal fraternity status.
The first semester quickly passed and the
only public utterance about the incident was a
statement by the V.F.W. concerning foreign
exchange students. For all practical purposes,
the issue had become a dead one.
Phi Psi, accepting the restrictions placed
upon it. attempted to keep the slate clean during the first semester in order to get off probation. Rumors, however, began to spread toward the end of November and early December
of the "dirty rushing" of Phi Psi and how the
Fraternity had not lived up to the party restrictions.
The big day came last week for Phi Psi and
all the Brothers reasonably expected that they
would be let off probation. However, they had
not counted on time dulling the minds of many
I.F.C. representatives.
Strange things happened at the IFJ.C. meeting on January 14. First, Phi Psi was not permitted to attend the meeting at which its most
vital interests were concerned. Dave Kagan,
President of Phi Psi. was told to sit outside
the meeting room. If anyone had any questions,
Kagan was to be called in to answer them. No
one had any questions.
Inside, even more mysterious things were
happening. The presiding officer asked for discussion on the Phi Psi case and the immediate
response was a motion not to even consider
the subject. Before anyone could even discuss
that motion and possibly present Phi Psi's side
of the story, a motion to end debate was entertained and passed.
A vote was then taken. But it was not in the
normal ballot procedure. Rather, it was a vote
by secret ballot.
The Phi Psi President was then told that
the I.F.C. had decided not to review the case

but that he should come back next week because they were going to discuss whether or
not to uphold Section Three of the penalty.
Section Three restricts Phi Psi from pledging anyone. Contained within that section is
a clause which says that if Phi Psi remains on
good behavior during first semester, then the
probation on pledging should be alleviated.
Good behavior is defined by the I.F.C. as not
being convicted of a rush violation.
If the I.F.C. does follow through on the
wording of the section, they could permit Phi
Psi to rush and take a pledge class next semester. However, Section One and Two are still
applicable. This means that Phi Psi cannot
have any parties for the rest of the year nor
participate in B.I.A. fraternity competition.
As might be imagined, Kagan and the other
sixty Brothers of Phi Psi were quite upset over
the actions of the I.F.C. They had been placed
on social probation to appease an irate public
and had been given the impression that if they
lived up to the restrictions placed on them,
their case would be reviewed at the end of the
first semester and that they would be taken off
probation.
After a semester of probation, they face an
I.F.C. that refuses even to consider their case,
let alone give them a chance to present their
side of the story. Still even more perplexing is
the fact that the Brothers of Phi Psi were not
even told what they had done wrong to deserve
a continuation of a punishment which no
longer had any relation to the situation it was
trying to alleviate.
There seemed to be a concensus at the I.F.C.
meeting that Phi Psi had been doing a lot of
"dirty rushing" and that they really did not
deserve to get off probation. But even if rumors
of specific rush violations were suitable grounds
for punishing Phi Psi, no one even stepped
forward to make any accusations or expositions. Since when has the judicial board condemned any fraternity for dirty rushing on
the basis of hearsay?
What the action of the I.F.C. boils down
to is quite simple. A punishment which had
been the means of soothing an angry public
was being extended to appease the personal
prejudices of a few representatives, thus endangering the stability of the fraternity system at Johns Hopkins. They have permitted
incidents of the past and personal grievances
with individual Brothers to reign supreme in
their criteria of evaluation. Rush has become
all important in their minds.
Phi Psi was pronounced guilty last Friday
without any semblance of a judicious trial. The
Brotherhood has not been told what it has
done wrong nor what it should do to get itself
off probation. It has acted on the understanding that good behavior would result in a favorable decision by the I.F.C. when the entire
case was reviewed. However, no such review
has yet taken place.
The I.F.C.'s action in this case can only
have detrimental effects upon the fraternity
system. By dealing with Phi Psi in the manner in which it did, it has demonstrated a
complete lack of responsibility. Little regard
was given to the Brothers who have been under
social probation for a semester. And little regard was given to the serious consequences
which may follow an action which threw away
all semblance of judicious and responsible
practice to study the first significant problem
ever before the I.F.C. The fraternity system at
Hopkins suffered a serious setback when the
I.F.C., in essence, allowed personal bias and
hearsay to govern its function as a deliberative
and judicial (i.e. rational and just) body.

REPUBLICAN BIAS

Block Repeal Of 14b!!
By GEOFFREY LEBAR
The recent mass transit strike
in New York City does not prove
that section 14b of the TaftHartley Act should be repealed.
Although it seems that such a
dramatic strike will affect the
repeal. The labor problem should
be considered on its merits.
The Republican minority in
the last session of Congress was
able to block the repeal of the
"right to work law" mainly because it offered a positive program to control the abuses of
labor. The repeal of section 14b
Is only symbolic. It affects only
19 of the least industrial states.
But the two major Republican
demands on labor would have a
revolutionary effect. RepubliCCM propose: I) to eliminate
all types of racial discrimination
from unions and 2) to provide

stiff penalities for unions using
membership dues to aid specific
political candidates.
This second provision would
not outlaw general money grants
to the parties. Of course, the
Democrats will claim that big
business serves the Republican
coffers, and therefore labor
should serve the Democrats
similarly. But that just is not so.
Contributions made in the name
of big corporations like Johnson
and Johnson, Dupont, General
Motors, etc., were made in equal
amounts to each political party
during the recent campaigns. It
may be true that certain business executives contribute to the
Republican party. But they do
not contribute company money.
Union leaders may contribute to
the Democratic party, but they

shoud not use membership dues.
Labor unions have a good
record on civil rights on paper,
but their membership lists are
often lilly white. At the recent
national AFL-CIO convention at
San Francisco, a newsman
counted only 20 negro delegates
out of a total of 922, and most
of them came from N.Y.C.

ber 20, 1964 on criminal charges
of depriving a Negro laborer of
employment opportunity. They
were accused of conspiracy and
"discrimination against a Negro
working man by depriving him
because of his raoe and color
of his civil rights to obtain employment."
This case was the first criminal
prosecution attempted under N.Y.
State's anti-discrimination laws,
On July 16, 1963, Barry Goldwater, of all people, introduced
an amendment to the Civil
Rights Act of 1964 which would
have outlawed labor union racial
discrimination. It was defeated
by the Democratic majority on
the Senate Judiciary Committee.

hearings on the Civil Rights Bill,
and said he agreed "in principle"
with the amendment proposed by
Senator Goldwater which "would
deny certification to labor unions
refusing membership because of
race."
While the unions were discouraging civil rights legislation,
the
Republican
conservative
senator from Texas, John Tower
was doing something for civil
rights. On October 1, 1963,
Tower voted to extend the life
of the Civil Rights Commission
for another year. The vote was
70-15; all 15 negative votes were
cast by southern Democrats.

The New York State Commission for Human Rights ruled on
March 4, 1964 that Local 28 of
the Sheet Metal Workers International Association has "automatically
excluded"
Negroes
from membership throughout
the union's 76 year history.

On August 14, 1963, John
638, and Jules Shurkman, a New
Two days later on July 18,
York lawyer, were indicted by a 1963, Willard Wirtz testified at Tower and Jacob Javits coN.Y. County grand jury Novem- Senate Commerce Committee sponsored an anti-discrimination rider to the Domestic Peace
Corps bill. It was defeated 49-41
with a large majority of the

Democrats not necessarily from

1964 and now is said to regret it.
He will introduce civil rights

The whole point of this discussion is not to condemn labor
unions or glorify Goldwater and
Tower's record. Neither is great,
and both will be better in the
future. But at least Republicans
can take credit for honestly

with concurrent attempts to negotiate, received 32.1% of those
voting. This represents 18% of
the undergraduate body. This
means 67.9% of those voting did
not agree with the administration policy. The mandate defeated its purpose and now we
can rightfully be branded as
militarists with a smattering of
pacifists among us. We just cannot win.
But we digress. We take issue
with the prerogative of the
Council to violate the confidence
of the student body. We would
bet guns to butter that those
who thundered "show the world
where we stand" would have
been silent as church mice had
the vote been for pulling out of
Vietnam. The motion would
never have reached the floor.
The comment was made in
Council that SDS would have
exploited the news; but no matter what the outcome it would
have been announced in the
News-Letter--and rightfully so.
Why the publicity? Surely, it
Is of little consequence that 18%
Hopkins'
undergraduates
of
voted to support administration
Vietnam policy. We submit that
such figures are unlikely to convince the Baltimore community
that its impression of Homewood
as a focal point for anti-war
sentiment is incorrect; in fact
that impression, fostered by unfavorable and injudicious newspaper coverage in October, has
undoubtedly dissipated. Hence,
Council action will serve only to
revive local antagonism, yet will
not lessen it.
Further, it seems to us that
the Council has proceeded with
undue haste on one count, yet
suffers from "over-inertia" on
another. Why, we wonder, did
the Council presume knowledge
of Baltimore opinion, yet feel
constrained to sample Hopkins'

feelings before making a definitive judgement similar to that
it had already made about the
surrounding
community?
It
seems reasonable to expect that
the Student Council, an official
organization of The Johns Hopkins University, would feel more
competent to make a priori
judgements about campus opinion. (This, in fact, was done
only implicitly in that it was obvious that most Council members assumed that student opinion would prove to favor administration policy in Vietnam). In
light of the foregoing the logical
and truly honest extension of
the Council's motives and intent
would have been to first conduct
a poll of the entire Baltimore
community to see whether, in
fact, Baltimore did view Hopkins in the manner the Council
so blithely assumed it did.
Admittedly, several of our
comments may border on the
facetious. Setting them aside, we
feel that the Council's action
was a grave mistake. Shelley
Earp is to be commended for
casting the decisive ballot which
ensured that the poll's results
would not be sent to President

Grad.Poll On Policy
By LOUIS GOLDBERG
Goldberg is a graduate student in the department of
Social Relations. He was the founder of the Hopkins Committee on Basiz Freedoms, and is currently on the steering
committee of the Graduate Student Viet Nam Coordinating
Committee.
At the same time that the Student Council was polling
undergraduate opinion on alternative American policies for
the War in Viet Nam last week, the Graduate Committee on
Viet Nani was conducting an identical poll among graduate
students. A considerably smaller number of graduate students voted than was the case for the undergraduates (170
graduate students voted as compared to 805 undergraduates). But while the smaller percentage of graduate students
polled (15% of the graduate students as compared to 54%
of the undregracls voted) raises some cautions in interpretation of the results-----due to questions concerning the representativeness of those who voted—the differences between the
distribution of graduate student votes across the 5 alternatives presented on the ballot, and that of the undergraduates.
Is large enough to indicate the existence of a sharp cleavage
in orientation toward the Viet Nam war between the two
groups.
For while the results of the poll show the Undergraduates as tending to favor "escalation the LBJ way," or an
even more Hawkish stance, the graduate students are clearly
more pacific—with "doves" predominating. Table I shows
these differences.

An enterprising group of Hopkins students with an interest in art and a flair for
business will open an art gallery in Baltimore early in February. Bruce Schwartz,
originator of the idea, explained "Good students in the fine arts have trouble showing
and selling their work. The National Student Art Exchange is set up strictly for
students, and this will give the best of them
the opportunity to display their work."
Works will be selected by faculties of the
respective schools of the contributors, by
local dealers, and by other qualified students. The first exhibit will feature work
from nearby universities, among them
American University, George Washington
University, University of Maryland, Goucher, and Hopkins.
Schwartz envisions the expansion of the
Art Exchange throughout the East. A gallery opening is planned for Hartford, Conn.,
In April, and one in New York by June.
Also planned is a national art show, to be
held next fall in Baltimore. Sponsored by
Baltimore businesses, it would feature
work contributed by students from the entire eastern United States,

Financial Support
Financial backing for the venture originated with a dozen students, mostly undergraduates, who issued stock at $50 a share
and incorporated last December 16 as the
National Student Art Exchange, Inc. The
stock has since split at five for two, with
shares currently selling at $20. The price
will rise to $30 in February. Presently, the
corporation has 78 stockholders, all students.
Schwartz stated that "we are going after
that segment of the market that can't at
ford to buy at $10,000 DeKooning, so in.
stead buys a $200 Chagal lithograph, of
which there are 10,000 copies in the United
States." Works will range from $5 to $200,
and works in every medium will be available.
Located at 833 N. Charles St., the gallery
will . be open Monday through Thursday,
from 1 to 9'p.m., and Friday and Saturday
from 1 p.m. to 1 a.m. Working on commission as brokers, students will be in cornplete charge of the gallery. Stockholders
will be given preference as salesmen, with
each getting a wage of $1 per hour.

360 German Flight Phi Psi Rush Under Review

(Continued from Page 1)

Hopkins' personnel Interested
In seeing Germany this summer
can avail themselves of a unique
opportunity. A group flight has
been arranged on which students,
faculty, alumni, employees and
their relatives are eligible. The
flight from New York to Frankfurt departs June 15 and returns
September 6.
Students interested in summer
jobs in Germany can apply at
the Lufthansa office on 330
North Charles Street. Students
must agree to work at least two
months, be 18 years old and have
United States or Canadian citizenship. Applicants should also
have a working knowledge of
German.
Jobs Available
Jobs are available in all areas
of Germany except West Berlin.
The exact location will often be
determined by the type of employment. Openings are available
in agriculture, industry, hotels
and restaurants, construction,

and hospitals.
A time lapse of at least two
months must be expected between application and the actual
offer of a job in Germany, so interested students should apply
promptly. No applications can be
accepted after February 28, 1966
for students planning to Germany independently. January 31,
1966 is the deadline for those who
plan to go on the Hopkins' group
flight.
Wages will generally range
from 60 cents to 80 cents an
hour. Though low by North
American standards, they are
quite adequate in Germany. A
specific statement of wages and
any extra form of renumeration,
such as meals and accommodations, will be included in every
job offer. Those interested in job
applications and/or further information on the group flight
should contact Mike Brenon
(235-4558) or,Mrs. Hazel Maines,
Jenkins 101, extension 429.

WATCH REPAIRING

Editors Note: The following was submitted by a member of the Phi Kappa Psi
Fraternity in clarification of the issue of its probation and its ,plea for reprieve
from the Inter-Fraternity Council.
Time often has a dulling effect upon our
minds. We often lose track of our original
goals and purposes over long periods of time,
and wind up heading in a direction which we
never intended in the first place.
Last Friday's meeting of the Inter-Fraternity
Council and its decision to do nothing about
the social probationary status of the Phi Kappa
Psi Fraternity is a clear example of how our
original intentions can be led astray. Let us
examine the situation which led to the placing
of Phi Psi on probation and then let us
weigh it against the action of the I.F.C.
. Eight pledges from Phi Psi created a community uproar by attempting to take down
the flag at Fort McHenry. Public sentiment
demanded immediate action. The administration acted quickly, placing the individuals involved on social probation and allocating penalties to each. The I.F.C. also acted, for the
Phi Psi brotherhood had accepted full responsibility for the action of their pledges, and
placed Phi Psi under social probation for a
year.
This was the second time that a fraternity
had been placed on social probation by the
I.F.C. However, the restrictions placed upon
Phi Psi were without precedent. Never before
had a fraternity been forbidden to engage in
B.I.A. fraternity competition or to pledge anyone. It was the understanding of all parties
concerned at the hearing last spring that these
measures had to be taken to appease public
commotion over the flag incident. Also the representatives of Phi Psi were led to believe that
their case would be reviewed at the end of the
first semester of this year. If the Fraternity
had lived up to the restrictions placed upon it
and if the incident had become a dead one
publicly, Phi Psis were led to believe that they
would be reinstated to normal fraternity status.
The first semester quickly passed and the
only public utterance about the incident was a
statement by the V.F.W. concerning foreign
exchange students. For all practical purposes,
the issue had become a dead one.
Phi Psi, accepting the restrictions placed
upon it. attempted to keep the slate clean during the first semester in order to get off probation. Rumors, however, began to spread toward the end of November and early December
of the "dirty rushing" of Phi Psi and how the
Fraternity had not lived up to the party restrictions.
The big day came last week for Phi Psi and
all the Brothers reasonably expected that they
would be let off probation. However, they had
not counted on time dulling the minds of many
I.F.C. representatives.
Strange things happened at the IFJ.C. meeting on January 14. First, Phi Psi was not permitted to attend the meeting at which its most
vital interests were concerned. Dave Kagan,
President of Phi Psi. was told to sit outside
the meeting room. If anyone had any questions,
Kagan was to be called in to answer them. No
one had any questions.
Inside, even more mysterious things were
happening. The presiding officer asked for discussion on the Phi Psi case and the immediate
response was a motion not to even consider
the subject. Before anyone could even discuss
that motion and possibly present Phi Psi's side
of the story, a motion to end debate was entertained and passed.
A vote was then taken. But it was not in the
normal ballot procedure. Rather, it was a vote
by secret ballot.
The Phi Psi President was then told that
the I.F.C. had decided not to review the case

but that he should come back next week because they were going to discuss whether or
not to uphold Section Three of the penalty.
Section Three restricts Phi Psi from pledging anyone. Contained within that section is
a clause which says that if Phi Psi remains on
good behavior during first semester, then the
probation on pledging should be alleviated.
Good behavior is defined by the I.F.C. as not
being convicted of a rush violation.
If the I.F.C. does follow through on the
wording of the section, they could permit Phi
Psi to rush and take a pledge class next semester. However, Section One and Two are still
applicable. This means that Phi Psi cannot
have any parties for the rest of the year nor
participate in B.I.A. fraternity competition.
As might be imagined, Kagan and the other
sixty Brothers of Phi Psi were quite upset over
the actions of the I.F.C. They had been placed
on social probation to appease an irate public
and had been given the impression that if they
lived up to the restrictions placed on them,
their case would be reviewed at the end of the
first semester and that they would be taken off
probation.
After a semester of probation, they face an
I.F.C. that refuses even to consider their case,
let alone give them a chance to present their
side of the story. Still even more perplexing is
the fact that the Brothers of Phi Psi were not
even told what they had done wrong to deserve
a continuation of a punishment which no
longer had any relation to the situation it was
trying to alleviate.
There seemed to be a concensus at the I.F.C.
meeting that Phi Psi had been doing a lot of
"dirty rushing" and that they really did not
deserve to get off probation. But even if rumors
of specific rush violations were suitable grounds
for punishing Phi Psi, no one even stepped
forward to make any accusations or expositions. Since when has the judicial board condemned any fraternity for dirty rushing on
the basis of hearsay?
What the action of the I.F.C. boils down
to is quite simple. A punishment which had
been the means of soothing an angry public
was being extended to appease the personal
prejudices of a few representatives, thus endangering the stability of the fraternity system at Johns Hopkins. They have permitted
incidents of the past and personal grievances
with individual Brothers to reign supreme in
their criteria of evaluation. Rush has become
all important in their minds.
Phi Psi was pronounced guilty last Friday
without any semblance of a judicious trial. The
Brotherhood has not been told what it has
done wrong nor what it should do to get itself
off probation. It has acted on the understanding that good behavior would result in a favorable decision by the I.F.C. when the entire
case was reviewed. However, no such review
has yet taken place.
The I.F.C.'s action in this case can only
have detrimental effects upon the fraternity
system. By dealing with Phi Psi in the manner in which it did, it has demonstrated a
complete lack of responsibility. Little regard
was given to the Brothers who have been under
social probation for a semester. And little regard was given to the serious consequences
which may follow an action which threw away
all semblance of judicious and responsible
practice to study the first significant problem
ever before the I.F.C. The fraternity system at
Hopkins suffered a serious setback when the
I.F.C., in essence, allowed personal bias and
hearsay to govern its function as a deliberative
and judicial (i.e. rational and just) body.

REPUBLICAN BIAS

Block Repeal Of 14b!!
By GEOFFREY LEBAR
The recent mass transit strike
in New York City does not prove
that section 14b of the TaftHartley Act should be repealed.
Although it seems that such a
dramatic strike will affect the
repeal. The labor problem should
be considered on its merits.
The Republican minority in
the last session of Congress was
able to block the repeal of the
"right to work law" mainly because it offered a positive program to control the abuses of
labor. The repeal of section 14b
Is only symbolic. It affects only
19 of the least industrial states.
But the two major Republican
demands on labor would have a
revolutionary effect. RepubliCCM propose: I) to eliminate
all types of racial discrimination
from unions and 2) to provide

stiff penalities for unions using
membership dues to aid specific
political candidates.
This second provision would
not outlaw general money grants
to the parties. Of course, the
Democrats will claim that big
business serves the Republican
coffers, and therefore labor
should serve the Democrats
similarly. But that just is not so.
Contributions made in the name
of big corporations like Johnson
and Johnson, Dupont, General
Motors, etc., were made in equal
amounts to each political party
during the recent campaigns. It
may be true that certain business executives contribute to the
Republican party. But they do
not contribute company money.
Union leaders may contribute to
the Democratic party, but they

shoud not use membership dues.
Labor unions have a good
record on civil rights on paper,
but their membership lists are
often lilly white. At the recent
national AFL-CIO convention at
San Francisco, a newsman
counted only 20 negro delegates
out of a total of 922, and most
of them came from N.Y.C.

ber 20, 1964 on criminal charges
of depriving a Negro laborer of
employment opportunity. They
were accused of conspiracy and
"discrimination against a Negro
working man by depriving him
because of his raoe and color
of his civil rights to obtain employment."
This case was the first criminal
prosecution attempted under N.Y.
State's anti-discrimination laws,
On July 16, 1963, Barry Goldwater, of all people, introduced
an amendment to the Civil
Rights Act of 1964 which would
have outlawed labor union racial
discrimination. It was defeated
by the Democratic majority on
the Senate Judiciary Committee.

hearings on the Civil Rights Bill,
and said he agreed "in principle"
with the amendment proposed by
Senator Goldwater which "would
deny certification to labor unions
refusing membership because of
race."
While the unions were discouraging civil rights legislation,
the
Republican
conservative
senator from Texas, John Tower
was doing something for civil
rights. On October 1, 1963,
Tower voted to extend the life
of the Civil Rights Commission
for another year. The vote was
70-15; all 15 negative votes were
cast by southern Democrats.

The New York State Commission for Human Rights ruled on
March 4, 1964 that Local 28 of
the Sheet Metal Workers International Association has "automatically
excluded"
Negroes
from membership throughout
the union's 76 year history.
Thomas P. McLinskey, ex-business agent of Steamlitters Local
On August 14, 1963, John
638, and Jules Shurkman, a New
Two days later on July 18,
York lawyer, were indicted by a 1963, Willard Wirtz testified at Tower and Jacob Javits coN.Y. County grand jury Novem- Senate Commerce Committee sponsored an anti-discrimination rider to the Domestic Peace
Corps bill. It was defeated 49-41
with a large majority of the
negative votes being cast by
Democrats not necessarily from
the South. Senator Tower voted
against the Civil Rights Bill in
1964 and now is said to regret it.
He will introduce civil rights
legislation again to alter any
segregationist image he may
have acquired.
The whole point of this discussion is not to condemn labor
unions or glorify Goldwater and
Tower's record. Neither is great,
and both will be better in the
future. But at least Republicans
can take credit for honestly
acknowledging the problem of
discrimination where it actually
exists outside of the South. The
party, including Mr. Goldwater,
has now avowed to consider civil
rights objectively aside from
liberal-conservative attitudes.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. JANUARY 21, 1966

eaVied•pandeace
(Continued from Page 4)
with concurrent attempts to negotiate, received 32.1% of those
voting. This represents 18% of
the undergraduate body. This
means 67.9% of those voting did
not agree with the administration policy. The mandate defeated its purpose and now we
can rightfully be branded as
militarists with a smattering of
pacifists among us. We just cannot win.
But we digress. We take issue
with the prerogative of the
Council to violate the confidence
of the student body. We would
bet guns to butter that those
who thundered "show the world
where we stand" would have
been silent as church mice had
the vote been for pulling out of
Vietnam. The motion would
never have reached the floor.
The comment was made in
Council that SDS would have
exploited the news; but no matter what the outcome it would
have been announced in the
News-Letter--and rightfully so.
Why the publicity? Surely, it
Is of little consequence that 18%
Hopkins'
undergraduates
of
voted to support administration
Vietnam policy. We submit that
such figures are unlikely to convince the Baltimore community
that its impression of Homewood
as a focal point for anti-war
sentiment is incorrect; in fact
that impression, fostered by unfavorable and injudicious newspaper coverage in October, has
undoubtedly dissipated. Hence,
Council action will serve only to
revive local antagonism, yet will
not lessen it.
Further, it seems to us that
the Council has proceeded with
undue haste on one count, yet
suffers from "over-inertia" on
another. Why, we wonder, did
the Council presume knowledge
of Baltimore opinion, yet feel
constrained to sample Hopkins'

feelings before making a definitive judgement similar to that
it had already made about the
surrounding
community?
It
seems reasonable to expect that
the Student Council, an official
organization of The Johns Hopkins University, would feel more
competent to make a priori
judgements about campus opinion. (This, in fact, was done
only implicitly in that it was obvious that most Council members assumed that student opinion would prove to favor administration policy in Vietnam). In
light of the foregoing the logical
and truly honest extension of
the Council's motives and intent
would have been to first conduct
a poll of the entire Baltimore
community to see whether, in
fact, Baltimore did view Hopkins in the manner the Council
so blithely assumed it did.
Admittedly, several of our
comments may border on the
facetious. Setting them aside, we
feel that the Council's action
was a grave mistake. Shelley
Earp is to be commended for
casting the decisive ballot which
ensured that the poll's results
would not be sent to President
Johnson—that would have multiplied the error. It is unfortunate that his refusal to conceive
of the poll as a "mandate" did
not persuade the Council. Finally, we note that 46% of Hopkins' undergraduates saw fit not
to participate in the poll. Such
inaction led directly to the
quandry in which we are now
involved. We hope that these
4F's do not continue to refuse
to exercise their franchise.
Very truly yours,
Larry S. Schmidt
'PC representative to the
Student Council
John M. Brickman
Senior Class representative
to the Student Council

Hop Theatre 'Alive'

Every Eliot hero, said Dr. Ellis,
suffers from either guilt or
angst, and in this way they are
mere reworkings of Eliot's tragichero prototypes; Sweeney and
Prufrock. Because of the single
inner conflict, they lack the
depth which a dramatic character must possess to be interesting.
Although the talk was well
organized and Dr. Ellis genial
and humorous, it did not rise
above mediocrity. His view of
Eliot as a poet rather than a
dramatist is obvious; Eliot himself made this point in a lecture
at Harvard University several
years ago.
The lecture was made most
effective by the reading of Colgate Salsbury, a well-known
actor who was one of the resident leads during the first season of Center Stage.

He is obviously a very accomplished actor. His stage appearance is dynamic and he has the
unique ability to believe completely in the person he is acting.
Even in one short scene, such as
Becket's sermon in Murder in
the Cathedral, he was able to
convey effectively to the audience what the Archbishop was
feeling.
However, in certain of his
readings, it was obvious that he
was ill prepared because of too
few rehearsals. In the reading
of The Cocktail Party his portrayal of Edward meandered
throughout the scene, probably
because he had never done the
part before.
The other actors, Ruth and
Robert Walsh and Rhea Feikin,
are local and have had most of
their experience in Baltimore.
Ruth Walsh read well with concentration and feeling, as did
Robert Walsh,
